choices.text: Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true
Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true
Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false
Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing the results of a study comparing two antihypertensive drugs in an Indian population. She comes across the term "p-value" in her statistical analyses. Which of the following best describes the interpretation of a p-value with regard to the probability related to the null hypothesis? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true

 

  • The p-value represents the likelihood of mistakenly rejecting a true null hypothesis. It serves as the threshold for determining statistical significance.
  • In essence, the p-value signifies the probability of erroneously rejecting a valid null hypothesis, leading to a Type I error.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true: This describes a correct decision where the null hypothesis is true, and the researcher correctly decides not to reject it. This scenario does not involve a p-value interpretation.

 

Option C. Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false: This describes a Type II error, where the null hypothesis is false, but the researcher fails to reject it. The p-value is not directly related to this scenario.

 

Option D. Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false: This describes a correct decision where the null hypothesis is false, and the researcher correctly rejects it. This is the goal of hypothesis testing but not the specific interpretation of a p-value.

 

Null Hypothesis

 

  • Hypothesis (H): Is an assumption about the status of a phenomenon
  • Null Hypothesis (H0): In Biostatistics, when we have to prove a particular hypothesis about difference between 2 regimens, we make Null Hypothesis (For examples, If we have to prove that new treatment is better than older treatment, H0 = new treatment is not better than older treatment).

questions.text: A 22-year-old female comes to the STI clinic with minimal vaginal discharge. On speculum examination, erosions are seen on the cervix. Which of the following kit should be given to this patient? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Grey

 

The patient presents with erosions on the cervix, which is indicative of cervicitis. According to the syndromic management guidelines for sexually transmitted infections (STIs), cervicitis is treated with the Grey Kit (Kit 1).

 

Educational Objective:  

 

STI color coded kits:

choices.text: Not given after 6 months of age
Given as monovalent and pentavalent vaccine

questions.text: All are true about Rotaviral vaccine except: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Not given after 6 months of age

 

The Rotaviral vaccine is included in the National Immunization Schedule of India and is primarily available in two types: Rotavac and Rotasil.
 

 

Note -

 

  • The vaccine is typically given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks of age under NIS, with the possibility of extending the schedule up to 12 months in cases of delayed immunization.
  • Both vaccines are live attenuated, but VP8 subunit vaccine is also available, offering more strain specificity and showing good results in infants, adolescents, and adults.

 

However, it is incorrect to state that the vaccine is "Not given after 6 months of age," as it can be administered up to 12 months of age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subunit vaccine: This statement is true as there is a subunit vaccine for rotavirus, specifically the VP8 subunit V protein vaccine, which has shown good results in various age groups.

 

Option C. Oral route of administration: This is correct. Rotaviral vaccines are given orally.

 

Option D. Given as monovalent and pentavalent vaccine: This is also correct. Rotavac is a monovalent vaccine, and Rotasil is a pentavalent vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rotaviral vaccine can be given up to 12 months of age according to the National Immunization Schedule of India.

choices.text: Not more than 10% of the people benefitted by the drug could be due to chance
90% of patients will be benefitted by giving the drug
90% of test results could have occurred by chance

questions.text: An investigative study was conducted in Mumbai wherein a promising new antihypertensive medication was evaluated for its potential efficacy. Initial clinical trials with a diverse cohort of patients with chronic hypertension revealed promising results in managing elevated blood pressure levels. The efficacy of the drug was measured meticulously, and upon analyzing the data, a p-value of < 0.10 was documented. Given this statistical information and considering the nuances of research interpretation, which of the following statements best elucidates the implications of this p-value in terms of the drug's effect? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Not more than 10% of the people benefitted by the drug could be due to chance

 

  • A P-value of less than 0.10 suggests that the likelihood of the drug's benefits occurring due to chance is no higher than 10%.

 

 INTERPRETATION:

 

  • Out of 100 repeated tests, a statistically insignificant difference will occur only 10 times, while a statistically significant difference will emerge 90 times.
  • There is a 10% probability of incorrectly concluding that a drug is beneficial when it is not, which can happen in statistical studies when deciding whether to accept or reject a null hypothesis.
  • The P value is compared to a predetermined threshold value 'a'; if the P value is less than 'a', the test is considered statistically significant, and the null hypothesis is rejected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The p-value is a statistical parameter used to evaluate whether the results of an experiment are statistically significant.
  • In this case, a p-value of < 0.10 suggests there is up to a 10% chance that the observed benefits from the antihypertensive drug could be due to random variation rather than a true effect of the drug.

questions.text: Which of the following steps is not included in WHO's STEP approach?[NEET  PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Therapeutic assessment

 

  • STEPwise approach to surveillance (STEPS) is a simple, standardized method by WHO for surveillance. It is of two types:
    • STEPwise approach to chronic disease risk factor surveillance
    • STEPwise approach to Stroke surveillance

choices.text: Analysis of variance

questions.text: Which of the following statistical tools is most suitable for establishing the optimal cutoff point to distinguish between positive and negative test results? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Receiver-operating characteristic curve

 

Explanation:

 

 

  • Receiver-operating characteristic (ROC) curve: An ROC curve plots the true positive rate (sensitivity) against the false positive rate (1-specificity) for different test result cut-off points. It allows for the visualization of the trade-off between sensitivity and specificity at various thresholds. The optimal threshold is often chosen based on the point on the curve closest to the top-left corner (maximizing true positives while minimizing false positives) or by considering the specific clinical context and the relative importance of sensitivity and specificity.  

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A. Analysis of variance (ANOVA): ANOVA is used to compare means between three or more groups. It is not relevant to determining the diagnostic threshold for a test.  
  • Option B. Pearson coefficient: The Pearson correlation coefficient measures the linear relationship between two continuous variables. It does not directly help in setting the threshold for a diagnostic test.  
  • Option D. Pre-test probability: This is the estimated likelihood of a patient having the condition before the test is conducted. While it can influence the interpretation of test results, it doesn't help in determining the optimal threshold itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ROC curve is the most appropriate tool for determining the optimal threshold for a diagnostic test, as it allows for the visualization and balancing of sensitivity and specificity at different cutoff points.

questions.text: What among the following can be employed for establishing the confidence interval in the Kaplan-Meier survival curve? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Hall-Wellner Band

 

  • The Kaplan-Meier survival curve is a graphical representation commonly used in survival analysis to display the probability of an event, typically survival, over time.
  • It is particularly useful when studying the time to a specific event, such as death or disease progression.
  • The Kaplan-Meier curve often incorporates bands around the survival estimate, which represent the confidence interval.
  • Hall-Wellner bands, Gill bands, and Nair's Equal Precision confidence bands are used for this purpose.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unequal precision band: Not a standard term used for Kaplan-Meier survival curves.

 

Option B. Hirshberg band: Not a recognized method for establishing confidence intervals in Kaplan-Meier survival curves.

 

Option C. Holmes band: Not a recognized method for establishing confidence intervals in Kaplan-Meier survival curves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Hall-Wellner band is employed for establishing the confidence interval in the Kaplan-Meier survival curve, providing a visual representation of the variability and confidence in the survival estimates.

questions.text: As a medical student, you're learning about the margin of error and its relationship with sample size. With three studies of different sizes (Sample 1: 1000, Sample 2: 800, Sample 3: 600), how would you order the expected margins of error from largest to smallest? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 3>2>1

 

  • Curve 1 exhibits the smallest margin of error, followed by Curve 2, and then Curve 3. Thus, the ranking is as follows: 3>2>1.
  • The depicted image showcases three normal distribution curves with varying sample sizes, all sharing the same mean but differing in standard deviation.
  • When the sample size decreases, the peak diminishes, and the curve adopts a flatter shape.
  • This signifies a broader confidence interval for the specified mean.
  • The width of the curve's base is directly linked to the margin of error.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The margin of error in a study is inversely related to the square root of the sample size.
  • This relationship implies that a larger sample size will generally lead to a smaller margin of error, assuming other variables like variance remain constant.

choices.text: To improve quality of life patient
Nothing is done in palliative care

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of stage IV non-small cell lung cancer presents with worsening dyspnea, non-productive cough, and uncontrolled pain despite current medication. He has declined further aggressive treatment. What stands true for Palliative care? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) To improve quality of life patient

 

Explanation:

 

  • Palliative care is a specialized medical care focused on providing relief from the symptoms and stress of a serious illness.
  • The primary goal of palliative care is to improve the quality of life for the patient. 
  • It involves treating pain and other distressing symptoms, providing psychological and spiritual care, and supporting the patient and their family to cope with the challenges of a serious illness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To cure disease: This is incorrect. Palliative care does not aim to cure the underlying disease but focuses on alleviating symptoms and improving the quality of life for both the patient and their family.

 

Option B. Do nothing to prolong life: Palliative care does not necessarily aim to prolong life, nor does it hasten death. It’s about enhancing the quality of life and may also indirectly prolong it by improving general health and well-being.

 

Option D. Nothing is done in palliative care: This is incorrect. Palliative care involves active and comprehensive management of various issues that arise with serious illnesses, including physical, emotional, social, and spiritual aspects of care.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Palliative care is crucial for improving the quality of life for patients with serious illnesses. 
  • It addresses a wide range of needs, ensuring the patient’s comfort and supporting the family through difficult times, emphasizing symptom management and personal support over curative treatments.

choices.text: National Maternity Benefit Scheme (NMBS)
Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK)
Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)
Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS)

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman delivers her baby in a public hospital in a rural district in India. She is informed by the healthcare provider that she will receive free transportation, medications, and diet during her hospital stay for both herself and her newborn. The provider further explains that this is part of a program introduced in 2011 under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) to ensure better health outcomes for mothers and newborns by expanding the scope of an earlier program, which initially focused only on maternal health. Which of the following programs is most likely being referred to?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK)

 

Explanation:

 

The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK), launched on June 1, 2011, under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), provides free and cashless services to pregnant women and their newborns, including free transport, medications, and diet. JSSK was introduced as an extension of the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY), which originally focused only on maternal health. JSSK expanded the scope to include newborn care up to 1 year of age, recognizing the need for comprehensive care for both mothers and infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) National Maternity Benefit Scheme (NMBS): This program was the predecessor to the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY). While NMBS provided financial assistance to pregnant women, it did not offer the broad range of free services that JSSK provides for both mothers and newborns.

 

Option C) Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK): RBSK is a child health program that focuses on early identification and management of health conditions in children up to 18 years of age. It is not designed specifically for maternal and newborn care.

 

Option D) Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS): ICDS focuses on improving the nutrition and health of children up to 6 years of age, as well as pregnant and lactating mothers, but it does not provide free medical services for deliveries like JSSK.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) provides free and cashless healthcare services to pregnant women and newborns in public health facilities, including transportation, medications, and diet. It was introduced in 2011 to extend the focus of the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY), which was initially aimed only at maternal health.

questions.text: A 40-year-old nurse in the infectious diseases ward is reviewing the necessary precautions for attending to patients with various primary diagnoses. For which of the following patients would she NOT need to take special airborne precautions? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Herpes Zoster 

 

  • While Herpes Zoster (shingles) can be contagious, it primarily requires contact precautions unless disseminated or in the immunocompromised, where it might necessitate airborne precautions if there are pulmonary symptoms.
  • Generally, for localized shingles in an immunocompetent patient, standard precautions along with contact precautions are sufficient, thus not routinely requiring airborne precautions like the diseases listed in the other options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculosis: Requires airborne precautions due to the high risk of transmission through airborne particles, particularly the respiratory droplets that can suspend in the air for extended periods.

 

Option C. Measles: Highly contagious and spreads through airborne transmission. Airborne precautions are essential due to measles' ability to remain airborne for up to two hours after the infected person has left the area.

 

Option D. Chicken Pox (Varicella): Also spread through airborne transmission, requiring similar precautions to measles to prevent the spread of the virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Measles, Tuberculosis, and chickenpox require airborne transmission precaution unlike herpes zoster.
  • The patient should be made to wear a mask for source control.
  • A fit-tested NIOSH-approved N95 or higher-level respirator should be used by the healthcare personnel whilst care delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best level of prevention of breast cancer? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Early diagnosis and treatment

 

Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial in the management of breast cancer. This involves screening methods such as mammography, which can detect cancer at an early stage when it is more likely to be treated successfully. Early treatment can significantly improve survival rates and outcomes for patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Specific protection: Specific protection involves preventive measures that protect against specific diseases, such as vaccinations or using protective equipment. Currently, there is no vaccine or specific protective measure that can prevent breast cancer.

 

Option C. Disability limitation: Disability limitation is part of tertiary prevention and focuses on minimizing the impact of an ongoing illness that has already caused some level of disability. It involves strategies to prevent complications and further disability. This is more applicable after a disease has been diagnosed and is not the best level of prevention for breast cancer.

 

Option D. Rehabilitation: Rehabilitation is also a part of tertiary prevention and aims to help individuals recover as much function as possible after a disease has caused disability. It includes therapies to restore physical, psychological, and social functioning. While important, it is not the best preventive strategy for breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early diagnosis and treatment (secondary prevention) are the most effective methods for preventing the progression of breast cancer, as they allow for early detection and intervention, significantly improving the chances of successful treatment and reducing mortality rates.

choices.text: Collect using your hand and discard in drain
Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket
Collect and throw outside in the environment
Broom it and discard in dustbin

questions.text: A medical student accidentally drops a sphygmomanometer, causing mercury spill on the floor. What is the most appropriate method to manage this spill? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket

 

  • Identify visible larger mercury beads and push together using Cardboards and collect using Syringe without needle.
  • Store collected mercury beads in an air tight plastic bag and label it properly. Put all the items that were used to pick up the mercury, including index cards or cardboard, eyedropper, contaminated tape, paper towels, and zipper-type bags into the trash bag. Carefully seal the trash bag that contains the mercury contaminated waste and dispose them properly.
  • Do not use a vacuum, broom or paint brush to clean up the spill. These methods can spread the mercury to other areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most appropriate method to manage a mercury spill is to collect it using paper/cardboard and place it in a water tube or bucket, then ensure safe and proper disposal.
  • Avoid direct contact, vacuuming, or sweeping the mercury.

questions.text: Based on the emblem as shown below, which of the following best describes the warning it signifies? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Radiation hazard

 

INTERNATIONAL RADIATION SYMBOL (TREFOIL)

 

  • Central circle of radius R, an internal radius of 1.5R and an external radius of 5R for the blades, which are separated from each other by 60°
  • Trefoil is black in the international version
  • Commonly referred to as a Radioactivity warning sign, but it is actually a warning sign of ionizing radiation
  • Includes X-ray apparatus, medical beam cannons and particle accelerators.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytotoxic waste: This waste includes materials that are toxic to cells, such as chemotherapy waste, but uses a different symbol.

 

Option B. Biomedical waste: This refers to waste generated from medical procedures, often marked with a biohazard symbol.

 

Option D. Biohazard: Indicates the presence of biological substances that pose a threat to human health, marked with a different symbol.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 38-year-old civil engineer is working on a construction project in an area recently affected by a devastating earthquake. To prevent future devastation, the local government has amended the building codes. These changes are aimed at ensuring structures in the area can better withstand seismic activity. The engineer reviews the changes to determine the best approach for the new construction project. This modification to the building codes is primarily an example of which phase of disaster management? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Disaster mitigation

 

  • The measures that are taken to prevent disasters from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies are part of disaster mitigation.
  • Mitigation involves measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing an emergency or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. In most cases mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system.

 

In Disaster Cycle, the steps involved are –

 

  1. Disaster Impact and Response: it involves search, rescue, first aid of the patients, triaging them according to the severity of their injuries and their likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention, tagging and identification of dead.
  2. Relief Phase or Disaster Containment by prompt assistance, epidemiological surveillance and disease control, vaccination, nutritional support.
  3. Rehabilitation involves restoration of the pre-disaster conditions. It takes into account assessment and restoration of water supply, food safety and supply, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, vector control.
  4. Disaster Mitigation involves measures aimed at reducing or preventing the hazards from causing any emergency or to dampen the effects of emergencies. It involves flood mitigation works, appropriate land-use planning, improved building codes and reduction or protection of vulnerable population and structures.
  5. Disaster Preparedness is a long-term programme of developmental activities which aims at strengthening the overall capacity and capability of the country to efficiently and effectively manage all the emergencies.  

 

   

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disaster mitigation involves proactive measures such as improved building codes to reduce the impact of future disasters, aiming to lessen vulnerability and enhance resilience against potential hazards.

questions.text: A bubonic outbreak has occurred within the community. What is the responsible vector for this condition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Xenopsylla cheopis

 

Xenopsylla cheopis, commonly known as a rat flea, serves as the carrier for the bubonic plague. This particular flea species can be recognized by its distinctive conical-shaped head, along with a thorax, abdomen, and three sets of legs.


 

  • Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis.
  • The reservoir of infections is wild rodents.
  • Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague.
  • Human plague mainly presents as:

 

 

Bubonic plague- This is the most common type of disease. There is fever along with painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes.

 

Pneumonic plague- It develops as a complication of bubonic-septicemic plague.

 

Septicemic plague- It occurs when the infection spreads to blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Species Phlebotomus argentipes: belongs to the group of sand fly. It transmits kala azar. Other diseases transmitted by sand flies are sandfly fever and oriental sore.

 

Option C. Ixodes Tick: transmits Lyme’s disease caused by Borrelia burgdorferi.

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito transmits malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xenopsylla cheopis (rat flea) is the primary vector responsible for transmitting the bubonic plague, caused by Yersinia pestis. Understanding the vector and transmission routes is crucial for controlling and preventing outbreaks.

questions.text: At the Urban Primary Health Centre (U-PHC), you are in charge of managing hypertension clinic services. You have 50 patients transferred from another healthcare unit for hypertension management; 40 of these patients are prescribed amlodipine (5mg, daily) and 10 are on lisinopril (10mg, daily) due to contraindications with amlodipine. Considering the need for continuous treatment and potential increases in patient numbers, calculate the number of tablets needed for the next month and determine the appropriate reorder factor. [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 3000, rf=2

 

Calculation -  

 

Requirement of Amlodipine

 

40 patients x 1 Tablet per day x 30 Days = 1200 Tablets

 

Requirement of Lisinopril

 

10 patients x 1 Tablet per day x 30 Days = 300 Tablets

 

Reorder factor (Rf) for drugs supplied every:

 

  • 1 Month - 2
  • 3 Months - 6
  • 6 Months – 12

 

For the given question,

 

Total of 1500 tablets are required and reorder factor is 2

 

Hence, Total tablets required = (1200 + 300) x 2 = 3000 Tablets

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Reorder Factor (rf): A reorder factor of 2 is commonly used for monthly resupply scenarios to account for unexpected increases in patient count or dosage adjustments, ensuring no interruption in patient care.

choices.text: Strength of correlation is same in A and B
Strength of the correlation is more in A than in B
Strength of the variation is more in B than A
Variation in variables is more with A than B

questions.text: A perinatologist is analyzing scatterplots from two research studies on the relationship between bone marrow density and gestational age. Study A shows data points tightly clustered along a trend line, while Study B shows data points that are more spread out but still follow a general trend line. Which statement correctly describes the relationship between bone marrow density and gestational age based on these observations? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Strength of the correlation is more in A than in B

 

  • Graph A represents stronger correlation than graph B.
  • More compact and close the dots are to the line, stronger is the relation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: You're mentoring a group of budding epidemiologists who are keen on understanding the nuances of different study designs. One of them is particularly interested in case-control studies. During your discussion, you decide to quiz them on aspects that are typically not inherent to case-control studies. Which of the given options would not usually be part of a case-control study? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Follow up 

 

  • Follow up is not a component of case-control studies.
  • These studies are retrospective and do not involve tracking subjects over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Matching: Process of selecting controls in a such a way that they are similar to cases (with regard to certain pertinent selected variables which may influence the outcome of disease, thereby distorting the results). It eliminates confounding.

 

Option C. Strength of association: In case-control studies, the strength of association is measured using the odds ratio (an estimate of relative risk).

 

Option D. Selection of study subjects: Essential in case-control studies, involving the selection of cases with the disease and controls without the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Case-control studies do not include follow-up of subjects but focus on matching, assessing the strength of association using odds ratios, and selecting cases and controls for analysis.

questions.text: A researcher is conducting an experiment in a controlled climate room to measure the air velocity. To assess the cooling effect of the air, the researcher uses an instrument that cools based on the surrounding air movement. What is the name of this instrument, as shown below?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Kata thermometer

 

Explanation:

 

The Kata thermometer is an instrument traditionally used to measure the cooling power of air, particularly in moving air environments. It works by measuring how quickly it cools down when exposed to airflow. In modern times, the Kata thermometer is more commonly used to assess low air velocity, determining the rate of heat loss in still air. It is particularly useful in controlled climates or laboratory conditions for evaluating air movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Anemometer: An anemometer is used to measure wind speed or air velocity, typically in outdoor environments, but it does not measure cooling effects like the Kata thermometer.

 

Option C) Barometer: A barometer measures atmospheric pressure, not air velocity or cooling power.

 

Option D) Hygrometer: A hygrometer is used to measure humidity levels in the air, not the cooling power or air velocity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Kata thermometer is used to measure the cooling power of air or low air velocity by determining the rate of heat loss. It is commonly used in laboratories or controlled climate settings.

questions.text: A community with a population of 20,000 documented 456 births in a year, of which 56 were stillbirths. The total number of deaths in the community for that year was 247, including 56 deaths within the first 28 days of life and 34 additional deaths after 28 days but before completing the first year of life. What is the infant mortality rate (IMR) for this community? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 225

 

 

In the given question, out of total 456 births, 56 were dead born. 

 

Therefore, the number of live births= 456-56 = 400.

 

In the same year, it is given that the number of deaths before 28 days is 56, and the number of deaths after 28 days but before 1 year is 34.

 

Hence, the total number of deaths of children < 1 year is 56 + 34 = 90

 

IMR = (90x1000)/400 = 900/4 = 225

 

Hence, the IMR is 225 per 1000 live births.

 

INFANT MORTALITY RATE

 

  • It is the number of deaths per 1000 live births of children under one year of age. It is the most sensitive indicator of availability and utilization of health care services in a country. Is most important indicator of health status of a community, level of living and effectiveness of MCH services in general. 
  • IMR is among ‘the best predictors of state failure’
  • It is a rate.
  • IMR of India (2023): 26.6 per 1000 live births; 
  • IMR of India - 35 per 1000 live births (NFHS-5 2019-21,); 28 per 1000 Live births (SRS, May 2022)
  • Is the second best indicator of socio-economic development of a country: Ultimate solution for lowering IMR lies in socio-economic development [Best indicator is U5MR]

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) for the community, calculated as the number of infant deaths per 1000 live births.
  • This rate serves as a crucial indicator of the health status and effectiveness of maternal and child health services in the community.

 

NOTE - UNICEF considers U5MR or CMR as ‘single best indicator of socio-economic development and well-being’ (even better than IMR)

questions.text: A resident in neurology is assessing a patient who recently sustained a traumatic brain injury using the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS). How should the resident describe the type of data obtained from the GCS? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ordinal scale data

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale represents ordinal data since the GCS score is categorized as mild, moderate, or severe, following a specific order of severity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nominal scale data: Data based on names without a specific order.

 

Option C. Alphanumerical data: Data that includes both letters and numbers, not applicable here.

 

Option D. Interval scale data: Data measured along a scale where each point is equidistant from the next, but GCS does not meet this criterion.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the options was initiated to ensure complete immunization of children? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Mission Indradhanush

 

Mission Indradhanush was launched in 2014 by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to ensure complete immunization of children who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. Later, it was modified in 2017 as Intensified Mission Indradhanush to achieve the same goal by December 2018, including 12 vaccine-preventable diseases. The program involves 4 rounds of immunization held for 7 days each month, and it replaced the previous focus on 7 diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MISSION INDRADHANUSH INCLUDES

 

  1. Polio
  2. Diphtheria
  3. Pertussis
  4. Tetanus
  5. TB
  6. Measles
  7. Hepatitis B
  8. Rota Virus
  9. MR
  10. IPV
  11. JE
  12. HiB
  13. PCV

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. During the social history taking, she mentions that she has started engaging in certain behaviors and rituals that align with her new community after recently moving to a different country. What is the term for this type of behavior acquisition? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Socialization

 

Explanation:

 

  • Learning and try to adapt to new community. This is known as Socialization
  • Socialization is the process by which individuals learn and adopt the norms, values, and behaviors appropriate to their society. 
  • Socialization is key in helping individuals function as members of their society, and it involves learning the language, norms, and rituals of the community.
  • This term directly applies to the scenario described, as the woman is adopting behaviors that align with her new community.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Custom: This term refers to a traditional and widely accepted way of behaving or doing something that is specific to a particular society, place, or time. Customs are the established patterns of behavior that can be objectively verified within a particular social setting

 

Option B. Culture: Is the learned behavior which is socially acquired. Culture is a broader term that includes knowledge, belief systems, art, morals, laws, and any other capabilities and habits acquired by individuals as members of society.

 

Option D. Mores: These are the moral norms, manners, or customs that are considered important for the welfare of a community and are enforced by social disapproval or formal sanctions if violated. Mores are a subset of social norms that include strong moral connotations and are seen as foundational to societal welfare.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

"Socialization" best captures the process the woman is undergoing as she adopts the practices of her new community.

questions.text: A study was carried out in three different states to analyze the average blood pressure within each community. Health workers were assigned to visit every household in these communities, and the mean blood pressure for each community was then calculated and compared. What study design best describes this research approach? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Cross-sectional study

 

Explanation:

 

  • Cross-sectional study: A cross-sectional study examines a population at a single point in time. It captures a snapshot of the population's characteristics, including health outcomes like blood pressure, at that specific moment. The study described in the question aligns with this definition as health workers collected blood pressure data from individuals in different communities at one particular time.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A. Cohort study: A cohort study involves following a group of individuals over time to observe the development of outcomes. This study does not involve any follow-up period.
  • Option C. Field trial: Field trials are interventional studies conducted on healthy individuals to assess the effectiveness of preventive measures.
     This study doesn't involve any intervention.  
  • Option D. Case-control study: A case-control study starts with individuals who have a specific outcome (cases) and compares them to those without the outcome (controls) to identify potential risk factors. This study design is not applicable here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A cross-sectional study is an observational study design that assesses a population at a specific point in time. It is often used to estimate the prevalence of a health condition or risk factor

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man has been diagnosed with tuberculosis. As part of his treatment plan, he is prescribed a combination of antitubercular drugs. While counseling him on the drug regimen, you explain the mechanisms of action of each drug. Which of the following combinations of statements accurately describe the mechanisms of some of the drugs used in treating tuberculosis? [INICET NOV 2022]

 

  1. Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis
  2. Pyrazinamide is an enzyme inducer
  3. Rifampicin is used only in the treatment of tuberculosis
  4. Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1, 4

 

1. lsoniazid - INH is activated by catalase peroxidase (formed by Kat G) enzyme of mycobacteria. It acts by inhibiting the formation of mycolic acid.

 

4. Bedaquiline - Act by inhibiting ATP synthase enzyme, can result in QT prolongation

 

Other Options:

 

2. Pyrazinamide - Possess the best sterilizing activity (can kill slow growing bacteria) and makes the medium sterile. Pyrazinamide inhibits trans-translation in Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is not an enzyme inducer.

 

3. Rifampicin - Act by inhibiting RNA polymerase of mycobacteria by binding to its β-subunit. It thus inhibits transcription. Uses of Rifampicin are:

 

  • Tuberculosis
  • Leprosy
  • DOC for Brucella (doxycycline + rifampicin)
  • Effective against Gram positive bacteria (including MRSA)
  • Effective against Gram negative bacteria (including Pseudomonas)
  • It was used for prophylaxis of meningococcus meningitis

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis.
  • Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase enzyme.
  • Pyrazinamide inhibits trans-translation
  • Rifampicin inhibit RNA polymerase

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with acute pain and swelling of the left great toe. There is no history of trauma. Synovial fluid analysis shows raised leukocytes. Lab investigations show normal serum uric acid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Acute gout

 

The patient presents with acute pain and swelling in the left great toe, a common presentation of acute gout. Despite normal serum uric acid levels, the clinical presentation and the findings from the synovial fluid analysis point towards acute gout.

 

Key Findings:

 

  1. Acute Pain and Swelling of the Left Great Toe: This is characteristic of acute gout, especially involving the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint.
  2. No History of Trauma: This excludes traumatic causes of joint pain.
  3. Synovial Fluid Analysis Shows Raised Leukocytes: Indicates an inflammatory arthritis.
  4. Normal Serum Uric Acid Levels: In 30-40% of acute gout cases, serum uric acid levels can be normal due to the uric acid being sequestered in the joint rather than in the bloodstream.

 

Acute Gout is a form of inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints, leading to intense pain and swelling. The first MTP joint is the most commonly affected site. Acute gout can present with normal serum uric acid levels, particularly during an acute attack, due to the uric acid being sequestered in the joint.

 

Diagnosis Confirmation: The diagnosis of gout is confirmed by joint aspiration and identification of negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals under polarized light microscopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudogout: This condition usually presents in elderly individuals and often involves the knee or wrist joints. The presence of chondrocalcinosis on X-ray and the involvement of joints like knee (MC), wrist or MCP joint (NOT first MTP joint) makes pseudogout less likely in this case.

 

Option C. Reactive Arthritis: This condition typically follows a gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection and involves multiple joints. There is no mention of such a history in this patient.

 

Option D. Septic Arthritis: This condition is usually associated with more severe systemic symptoms like fever and a more aggressive clinical course. The patient's presentation does not match the typical features of septic arthritis.

 

Educaitonal Objective:

 

Acute gout can present with normal serum uric acid levels, especially during an acute attack, and the involvement of the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint is highly characteristic of this condition.

questions.text:
Many GPCR receptors act via increase in cAMP. There are several steps involved in this mechanism as given below. Which of the following is correct sequence of events in cAMP signal transduction pathway? (INICET May 2024)

 

Steps involved


1. Activation of adenylate cyclase
2. Activation of PKA
3. Conversion of ATP to cAMP
4. Phosphorylation of target proteins
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 2 and 4

 

The correct sequence of events in the cAMP signal transduction pathway is:

 

  1. Activation of adenylate cyclase
  2. Conversion of ATP to cAMP
  3. Activation of PKA
  4. Phosphorylation of target proteins

 

Therefore, the correct answer is: B. 1, 3, 2 and 4

questions.text: What type of joint is demonstrated in the highlighted region of the vertebral articulation shown? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Synovial

 

The joint marked in the above image is a synovial joint called the costotransverse and costovertebral joint.

 

These are the most common type of joints in the body. The articulating ends of the bones in these joints are covered with articular cartilage. These bones are enclosed within an articular capsule which has an outer fibrous layer (giving it strength) and an inner synovial membrane which secretes synovial fluid (providing lubrication and nutrients to the joint). Examples include the knee joint, elbow joint, and many others.

 

They are diarthrotic, meaning they are freely movable. The exact range of movement and type of movement (e.g., hinge, pivot, ball-and-socket) varies depending on the specific joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndesmosis: This is a type of fibrous joint where the bones are joined by a ligament or a membrane. The most commonly referred syndesmosis is the one between the tibia and fibula in the leg, held together by the interosseous membrane and the anterior and posterior tibiofibular ligaments.

 

  • It allows for a slight movement (making it amphiarthrotic), particularly when the foot is dorsiflexed or plantarflexed.

 

Option B. Synarthrosis: This term describes a joint that allows very minimal or no movement. It encompasses several types of joints including sutures (between skull bones), gomphoses (between a tooth and its socket), and synchondroses (which we'll discuss next).

 

  • These are largely immovable joints. They serve to provide stability in certain areas of the body, like the skull, where movement is not desired.

 

Option C. Synchondrosis: This is a subtype of synarthrosis, and it's a type of cartilaginous joint where bones are joined together by hyaline cartilage. A classic example is the joint between the first rib and the sternum, or the epiphyseal plates in growing bones.

 

  • They are immovable (synarthrotic). The primary purpose of these joints is to allow growth of the bone while providing stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Description of the joint present in the thoracic region are as follows:

questions.text: Which of the following Immunohistochemistry marker is used in Cyclin D1 negative Mantle cell lymphoma? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SOX11

 

Mantle cell lymphoma is an uncommon lymphoid neoplasm that makes up about 2.5% of NHL.

 

The tumor cells closely resemble the normal mantle zone B cells that surround germinal centers.

 

Typically, the proliferation consists of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply clefted (cleaved) nuclear contours.

 

Immunohistochemistry - Mantle cell lymphomas express high levels of cyclin D1. Most tumors are also express CD19, CD20, and moderately high levels of surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with κ or γ light chain). It is usually CD5+ and CD23-, which helps to distinguish it from CLL/SLL. The IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation, supporting an origin from a naive B cell.

 

Cyclin D1 (CCND1) protein overexpression and/or the t(11;14) (q13;q32) translocation are the pathognomonic hallmarks of mantle cell lymphoma (MCL). SOX11 expression serves as a specific biomarker in cases lacking both t (11;14) and cyclin D1 protein but having a gene expression profile suggestive of MCL. SOX11 expression is associated with bad prognosis in mantle cell lymphoma.

 

  • MYD88: Associated with Waldenström macroglobulinemia.
  • Annexin V: Generally used in apoptosis studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DDs of NHL: -

questions.text: In given image, nucleus of marked nerve is related to (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cervical spinal segment

 

The nerve marked in the image is the phrenic nerve. The phrenic nerve is primarily responsible for innervating the diaphragm, which is crucial for breathing. The mnemonic "3, 4, 5 keeps the diaphragm alive" helps to remember that the phrenic nerve arises from the cervical spinal segments C3, C4, and C5. This nerve travels downward, passing in front of the lung root, to reach the diaphragm.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midbrain: The midbrain is not involved in the origin of the phrenic nerve. The midbrain primarily deals with functions such as vision, hearing, motor control, sleep/wake, arousal, and temperature regulation.

 

Option B. Pons: The pons is involved in various functions including breathing, communication between different parts of the brain, and sensations such as hearing, taste, and balance. However, it does not give rise to the phrenic nerve.

 

Option C. Medulla: The medulla oblongata regulates vital functions such as heart rate, breathing, and blood pressure. While it contains nuclei for several cranial nerves, it is not the origin of the phrenic nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phrenic nerve originates from the cervical spinal segments C3, C4, and C5, and is essential for diaphragm movement and breathing.

choices.text: Gene Amplification is done irrespective of Her 2 Neu status

questions.text: In breast cancer, FISH for gene amplification will be done based on which of the following IHC staining for Her-2/neu? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2+

 

In the context of breast cancer, the Her-2/neu status is typically assessed by Immunohistochemistry (IHC). The Her-2/neu protein overexpression is graded on a scale of 0 to 3+ based on the intensity and completeness of membrane staining. This grading is crucial in guiding further testing and treatment decisions.

 

  • IHC 0 or 1+: These scores indicate no or low levels of Her-2/neu expression, respectively. Tumors with these scores are considered Her-2 negative, and no further testing for gene amplification is typically needed.
  • IHC 2+: This score is considered equivocal. When a tumor shows a 2+ result on IHC, it suggests an intermediate level of Her-2/neu expression. Because this result is not definitively positive or negative, Fluorescence in Situ Hybridization (FISH) testing is recommended to assess for gene amplification of Her-2/neu. FISH is a more sensitive and specific test that directly detects the amplification of the Her-2/neu gene, providing definitive information about the tumor's status.
  • IHC 3+: A score of 3+ indicates a high level of Her-2/neu protein overexpression. Tumors with this score are considered Her-2 positive and typically do not require further FISH testing, as the overexpression is sufficient to warrant Herceptin (trastuzumab) therapy.

 

Herceptin is a targeted therapy that specifically inhibits the Her-2/neu receptor, which is overexpressed in some breast cancers, leading to more aggressive tumor behavior. Therefore, determining the correct Her-2/neu status through IHC and, if necessary, confirming with FISH is crucial in selecting the appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1+: IHC 1+ is considered Her-2/neu negative, and FISH testing is generally not indicated in these cases.

 

Option C. 3+: IHC 3+ is strongly positive for Her-2/neu, making FISH testing unnecessary since the high expression level is sufficient to guide treatment decisions.

 

Option D. Gene Amplification is done irrespective of Her 2 Neu status: This option is incorrect because FISH testing for gene amplification is specifically indicated in cases with an equivocal IHC result (2+), not irrespective of Her-2/neu status.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH for Her-2/neu gene amplification is performed when the IHC result is 2+, as this score is considered equivocal, requiring further testing to determine the appropriate therapeutic approach.

choices.text: Release of noradrenaline at synaptic cleft
Selectively and irreversibly inhibits nicotinic receptors

questions.text: An elderly woman received a Botox injection for the treatment of wrinkles.  Which of the following is the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibits the release of acetylcholine

 

  • The botulinum toxin works by preventing acetylcholine from entering the synaptic cleft. Acetylcholine is exocytosed by SNARE protein, which is broken down by botulinum toxin. Consequently, it prevents acetylcholine from being released.
  • Other agents that regulate the level of Ach in the synapse are:
    • Hemicholinium acts by inhibiting choline uptake (the rate limiting step in the synthesis of acetylcholine)
    • Vesamicol inhibits the uptake of Acetylcholine into the vesicles.
    • Physostigmine inhibits the breakdown of Ach at the synaptic cleft by the action of Acetylcholine esterase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Release of noradrenaline at synaptic cleft: Botulinum toxin does not facilitate the release of noradrenaline. Its primary action is on the cholinergic neurons where it inhibits the release of acetylcholine.

 

Option C. Selectively and irreversibly inhibits nicotinic receptors: Botulinum toxin does not directly inhibit nicotinic receptors. Instead, it prevents the release of acetylcholine, which means there is no neurotransmitter available to bind to and activate the nicotinic receptors.

 

Option D. Stimulates muscarinic and nicotinic receptors: Botulinum toxin does not stimulate muscarinic or nicotinic receptors. In fact, it decreases neurotransmission by preventing the release of acetylcholine, which would otherwise stimulate these receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Botulinum toxin inhibits the release of acetylcholine by cleaving SNARE proteins, thereby preventing neurotransmission at the neuromuscular junction and leading to muscle relaxation.
